title: Lizzo performs at 7th Annual We Can Survive concert amid plagiarism claims
text:
She was hit with a second plagiarism accusation over her chart-topping single Truth Hurts last week when two songwriters claimed they helped her write her iconic '100 per cent that b***h' lyric.

But Lizzo was brushing off the drama and focusing on entertaining her fans, taking to the stage to perform during the 7th Annual We Can Survive event at The Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles on Saturday, presented by AT&T.

The 31-year-old singer looked incredible as she put on a high-energy performance, showing off her killer curves in a white crop top and high-waited trousers seemingly emblazoned with a reference to the phrase in question.

'100 per cent that b***h': Lizzo took to the stage to perform during the 7th Annual We Can Survive event at The Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles on Saturday, presented by AT&T

Lizzo exuded confidence as she paraded around the stage in her pinstripe trousers, featuring the words '100 per cent' in gold running down her left leg.

Upon turning around, the pants boasted the words 'that b****h' written across her derriere.

The chart-topping star delighted the crowd with her set, treating them to a rendition of her biggest hits.

Her hair was styled in loose curls and she matched her hoop earrings to the gold sequins.

Making a statement: Lizzo exuded confidence as she paraded around the stage in her pinstripe trousers, which were emblazoned with a gold '100 per cent' running down her left leg

Cheeky: Upon turning around, the pants boasted the words 'that b****h' written across her derriere

Fan favourite: The chart-topping star delighted the crowd with her set, treating them to a rendition of her biggest hits

Wow: The 31-year-old singer looked incredible as she put on a high-energy performance

It was claimed last week that one her song Truth Hurts' iconic line —'I just took a DNA test turns out I'm 100 percent that b***h'— might have been written by someone else.

Brothers Justin and Jeremiah Raisens are asking for five percent each for helping create the line, which they claim happened during a songwriting session for a different song with the 31-year-old hitmaker in April 2017.

Making the allegations public for the first time last Tuesday, the songwriters told the New York Times they wrote a song called Healthy with Lizzo that featured a near identical line.

Allegations: It was claimed last week that one her song Truth Hurts' t iconic line — 'I just took a DNA test turns out I'm 100 percent that b***h'— might have been written by someone else

'We were never contacted about being credited for the use of the parts of Healthy (melody, lyrics, and chords) that appear in Truth Hurts', Raisen wrote in a caption to the video.

'We’ve tried to sort this out quietly for the last two years, only asking for 5% [songwriting royalties] each, but were shut down every time.'

The brothers admitted they found the line on Twitter, originally penned by British singer Mina Lioness, who had accused Lizzo of plagiarising the phrase last year.

Currently Lizzo (born Melissa Jefferson), Ricky Reed, Tele and Jesse Saint John are credited as writers on the song.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 chart for six weeks straight this year.

In a statement to the New York Times, Lizzo's lawyer, Cynthia S. Arato, denied their claims: 'The Raisens are not writers of Truth Hurts.

Behind the claim: Brothers Justin and Jeremiah Raisens are asking for five percent each for helping create the line, which they claim happened during a songwriting session for a different song with the 31-year-old hitmaker in April 2017

Songwriting session: 'We were never contacted about being credited for the use of the parts of Healthy (melody, lyrics, and chords) that appear in Truth Hurts,' they wrote in similar Instagram posts

'They did not help write any of the material that they now seek to profit from, which is why they expressly renounced any claim to the work, in writing, months ago.'

The brothers went further and shared a video to Instagram that overlapped Lizzo's vocals from Healthy and Truth Hurts singing the line.

She sang, 'I did a DNA test and found out I'm 100% that b****,' in a strikingly similar melody - just in a different key.

Lizzo's camp does agree the writing session produced the 'DNA test' line. The dispute lies in who created the lyric.

The singer's representatives say she made it on her own, but the brothers say she tailored her voice to the line they created.

Back in the day: Lizzo is pictured with the songwriters in the video they posted comparing her vocals on the line in Healthy and Truth Hurts

The Raisens' claim they joined the singer, Saint John and Yves Rothman to pen a track named Healthy, but they were never contacted about Healthy's music, lyrics or tempo being used.

Justin said, 'It's not fair that we were not included,' adding that the brothers suffered 'emotional distress' due to the situation.

They did praise Lizzo, however, saying: 'The last thing we want to do is throw any negativity toward Lizzo’s momentum and movement as a cultural figure.'

Truth Hurts was made eligible for the Grammy's, despite being released two years ago, and the singer is positioned as a likely candidate for Best New Artist.

Lizzo was first accused of plagiarism in February 2018 by British artist Mina Lioness, who originally tweeted the line in February 2017.

Legal battle: Lizzo's camp does agree the writing session produced the 'DNA test' line. The dispute lies in who created the lyric

Speaking out: Lizzo was first accused of plagiarism in February 2018 by British artist Mina Lioness, who originally tweeted the line in February 2017. She later called Lizzo's camp 'brazen'

Mina called out LIzzo on Twitter, saying: 'Everyone believes those were your words, when in fact they were mine. My creativity, my wit and my comedy'.

However, Lizzo replied that she was 'inspired' by a viral meme and had never seen the tweet.

This summer, Lizzo tried to copyright the phrase '100% that bitch' to use on merchandise.

In August, Mina tweeted: 'What I cannot get over is how brazen Lizzo and her team have been in ignoring my whole presence.

'They’re doing it because they know I have no capital to address her. I’m just the poor Black girl from London that don’t have a dog in the fight.'

MailOnline has contacted Lizzo's representatives for comment.
